content: easy knitted baby quilt by mary lee miller © 2023 i was working through my yarn stash looking for yarn for a baby project and found a few skeins of a mystery yarn that was a nice blue but had some other colors also spun in for interest i worked up a few swatches with it and everything i tried was too detailed to work with the yarn then i decided to go simple and do something like a block quilt pattern and this is the result the pattern is simple knit/purl so should be easy for a beginner yet still provides enough detail to make it interesting to knit the quilt consists of a two-part seed stitch and stockinette border framing a simple block pattern using stockinette and reverse stockinette the yarn i used was unlabeled but i believe it to be a very soft cotton/acrylic blend with the needles i chose the piece has a very soft hand and drapes easily if you choose a firmer yarn or smaller needles the hand and drape will be different finished size approximately 30 x 33 in my sample but will depend on your gauge and yarn the pattern is easily adjusted gauge is irrelevant but work up a swatch with both seed stitch and stockinette to compute how big your piece will be in case you want to make adjustments the pattern can be modified by changing the border widths the number of row of blocks or the block size as desired my gauge was approx 17 stitches and 22 row = 4 in stockinette after blocking materials  5 skeins worsted 4 yarn @ 3 5 oz / 100 grams and 180 yards  us size 8 5 mm straight needles or circular if you prefer  yarn needle  4 stitch markers stitches seed stitch worked over an odd number of stitches * k1 p1 repeat from * to last stitch k1 stockinette row 1 rs knit row 2 ws purl repeat row 1 & 2 reverse stockinette row 1 rs purl row 2 ws knit repeat row 1 & 2 1 of 4 easy knitted baby quilt by mary lee miller © 2023 instructions this blanket is very easy for anyone with the basic knitting skills of knit and purl the finished piece looks more difficult than it is to actually make the pattern maintains a two-part border of seed stitch and stockinette framing a block-based quilt panel the panel is created using alternating blocks of stockinette and reverse stockinette the blocks switch at intervals that create approximate squares based upon my gauge you may want to use your own gauge to determine whether the blocks you knit will be square or rectangular either shape will work but i was going for squares in my sample start at outer border cast on 145 stitches row 1 through 19 or for 2 5 inches * k1 p1 repeat from * across to last stitch k1 seed stitch ideally
